body: Is this function used anywhere outside of tests?
Sure, done via 83efd146aee45de91454b098fcdeacf51d04658b (includes an extra comment)
Yes, in the users application code. It enables an optional optimization for allocations (3 allocations and 448B per request with no vars, see 1465de4bc6d23ba2349b3823685fb946bfe11d11).
Makes sense, thanks! I wish we had an interface for "Router" that would define this contract to make that relationship more clear - however that'll fall outside the scope of this PR ðŸ™‚

Hi @eh-steve, can we add an example in the docs? I agree you already explain the use case briefly in the PR comment. Others who will go through the package documentation should understand its use case properly.

```go
func main() {

	r := mux.NewRouter()
	r.Host("{domain}").
		Path("/{group}/{item_id}").
		Queries("some_data1", "{some_data1}").
		Queries("some_data2", "{some_data2}").
		HandlerFunc(Func).
		Name("article")
	fmt.Println(r.Get("article").GetVarNames())
	http.ListenAndServe(":8000", r)

}
```` 

`GetVarNames` will print `[domain group item_id some_data1 some_data2] <nil>`
Can we add an example in the `README.md` file and add test cases to validate the implementation.
I've added some, not sure how useful they are, but lemme know?

~Change expected to this:~

```go
expected := []string{"domain", "group", "item_id", "some_data1", "some_data2", "some_data3"}
```
~You can use `reflect.DeepEqual` to check if `varNames`  and `expected` slice are equal or not.~
Added a review comment for the test case.
This is deliberate, since I don't want to enforce any guarantees about slice ordering in the test.
Again, this is deliberate, since I don't want to enforce any guarantees about slice ordering in the test

* one last comment, rename this file to `example_route_vars_test.go`
* change `package mux` --> `package mux_test`
* Add missing imports at line number 3
Oops, missed that!
how would err ever get set here? we initialise it but never git it a value unless I'm misunderstanding?
To add: err will always be nil so the error check below is unreachable code.
Don't create tests like this. Use build flags please.

> We aren't testing mux itself here.

Exactly, I just only wanted to update readme file. Just to show case that proposal change is valid I wrote these test cases. If we all agree to `README.md` change. I would be happy to remove these test cases because It is not doing anything as you already mentioned.

Let me know what do you guys think?

cc @elithrar  @casserlyprogramming
OOPS! I missed it there. I think I forgot to remove the below if condition. Thank you for pointing it out.
Addressed the above review comment.
`path` is never initialized
thanks for pointing it out. I have fixed the issue.
